psychinterpreter: Getting Started

A Basic Usage Example with Big Five Personality Data

Matthias Kloft

2025-11-03

Source: vignettes/articles/01-Basic_Usage.qmd

Overview

This document demonstrates the functionality of the psychinterpreter package using the Big Five personality data from the psych package. The Big Five Inventory (BFI) is a widely-used personality assessment that measures five major dimensions of personality: Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, and Neuroticism.

We’ll test all major features of psychinterpreter including:

  • Basic factor analysis interpretation
  • Persistent chat sessions for efficient LLM usage
  • Export functionality across multiple formats
  • Advanced interpretation features

Setup and Data Preparation

Code
packages <- c(
  "psychinterpreter",
  "ellmer",
  "psych",
  "lavaan",
  "mirt",
  "dplyr",
  "here",
  "pander"
)
# Load required packages using pacman
if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman")
Loading required package: pacman
Code
pacman::p_load(char = packages)

# Load the BFI dataset and dictionary
data("bfi")
data("bfi.dictionary")

Preparing the BFI Data

Exclude demographic variables for factor analysis

Code
bfi <- bfi[,1:25]
bfi.dictionary <- bfi.dictionary[1:25, ]

Show the first few rows of the BFI data:

Code
head(bfi,10)

Display the BFI dictionary showing item descriptions:

Code
bfi.dictionary |> select(Item) |> as.data.frame()

Factor Analysis

Determining Number of Factors

Code
# Parallel analysis to determine optimal number of factors
pa_result <- fa.parallel(
  bfi,
  fa = "fa",
  n.iter = 100,
  use = "pairwise.complete.obs",
  main = "Parallel Analysis: BFI Data"
)
Parallel analysis suggests that the number of factors =  6  and the number of components =  NA

Exploratory Factor Analysis Using 6 Factors

Perform FA with 6 factors identified by the parallel analysis

Code
fa_result <- fa(
  bfi,
  nfactors = pa_result$nfact,
  rotate = "oblimin",
  fm = "ml"
)
summary(fa_result)

Factor analysis with Call: fa(r = bfi, nfactors = pa_result$nfact, rotate = "oblimin", fm = "ml")

Test of the hypothesis that 6 factors are sufficient.
The degrees of freedom for the model is 165  and the objective function was  0.36
The number of observations was  2800  with Chi Square =  1013.79  with prob <  4.6e-122

The root mean square of the residuals (RMSA) is  0.02
The df corrected root mean square of the residuals is  0.03

Tucker Lewis Index of factoring reliability =  0.922
RMSEA index =  0.043  and the 90 % confidence intervals are  0.04 0.045
BIC =  -295.88
 With factor correlations of
      ML2   ML1   ML3   ML5   ML4   ML6
ML2  1.00  0.25 -0.18 -0.10  0.02  0.18
ML1  0.25  1.00 -0.22 -0.31 -0.19 -0.06
ML3 -0.18 -0.22  1.00  0.19  0.19 -0.03
ML5 -0.10 -0.31  0.19  1.00  0.25  0.14
ML4  0.02 -0.19  0.19  0.25  1.00  0.02
ML6  0.18 -0.06 -0.03  0.14  0.02  1.00
Code
# Extract loading matrix for interpretation
loadings_matrix <- unclass(fa_result$loadings) |> as.data.frame()
round(loadings_matrix, 2)
Code
# Extract factor correlation matrix
factor_cor_mat <- fa_result$Phi |> as.data.frame()
round(factor_cor_mat, 2)

Chat Setup

Set up persistent chat session

Code
chat <- chat_fa(
  provider = "ollama",
  model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",
  # set temperature and seed for reproducibility
  params = params(temperature = 0, seed = 42)
)

print(chat)
Factor Analysis Chat Session
Provider: "ollama"
Model: "gpt-oss:20b-cloud"
Created: 2025-11-03 03:12:27.869068
Interpretations run: 0

Interpreting Factor Analysis Results

Create variable information dataframe from BFI dictionary

Code
variable_info <- data.frame(
  variable = rownames(bfi.dictionary),
  description = bfi.dictionary$Item,
  stringsAsFactors = FALSE
)

head(variable_info, 10)

We now generate factor interpretations using the specified LLM:

Code
result <- interpret_fa(
    loadings = loadings_matrix,
  variable_info = variable_info,
  cutoff = 0.3,
  n_emergency = 2,
  additional_info = NULL,
  factor_cor_mat = factor_cor_mat,
  sort_loadings = TRUE,
  word_limit = 100,
  max_line_length = 80,
  silent = FALSE,
  echo = "none",
  output_format = "markdown",
  heading_level = 2,
  suppress_heading = TRUE,
  chat_session = chat
)
ℹ The description column is a factor - converting to character
ℹ Using existing chat session: Ollama "gpt-oss:20b-cloud"

  • Factor 1 (9.2%): Negative Affect
  • Factor 2 (7.9%): Introversion
  • Factor 3 (7.7%): Conscientiousness
  • Factor 4 (6.8%): Agreeableness
  • Factor 5 (6.3%): Openness
  • Factor 6 (3.1%): Low Openness/Agreeableness

Factor Correlations

  • ML2: ML1 = .25, ML3 = -.18, ML5 = -.10,
    ML4 = .02, ML6 = .18
  • ML1: ML2 = .25, ML3 = -.22, ML5 = -.31,
    ML4 = -.19, ML6 = -.06
  • ML3: ML2 = -.18, ML1 = -.22, ML5 = .19,
    ML4 = .19, ML6 = -.03
  • ML5: ML2 = -.10, ML1 = -.31, ML3 = .19,
    ML4 = .25, ML6 = .14
  • ML4: ML2 = .02, ML1 = -.19, ML3 = .19,
    ML5 = .25, ML6 = .02
  • ML6: ML2 = .18, ML1 = -.06, ML3 = -.03,
    ML5 = .14, ML4 = .02

Detailed Factor Interpretations

Factor 1 (ML2):: Negative Affect

Number of significant loadings: 5
Variance explained: 9.22%
Factor Correlations: ML1 = .25, ML3 = -.18, ML5 = -.10,

ML4 = .02, ML6 = .18

Variables:

  1. N2, Get irritated easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .851)
  2. N1, Get angry easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .851)
  3. N3, Have frequent mood swings. (Positive, Strong, .639)
  4. N5, Panic easily. (Positive, Moderate, .402)
  5. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Weak, .389)

LLM Interpretation:
ML2 represents Negative Affect, capturing the tendency toward emotional instability. The factor is defined by strong loadings on anger (N1), irritability (N2), mood swings (N3), sadness (N4), and panic (N5), all reflecting rapid shifts in mood and heightened sensitivity to stress. Convergent validity is evident as all items measure negative emotionality, while discriminant validity is supported by low loadings on the other personality dimensions. Correlations show modest positive links with Introversion (ML1) and Extraversion (ML6) but remain largely distinct, underscoring its unique contribution to the personality structure.

Factor 2 (ML1):: Introversion

Number of significant loadings: 7
Variance explained: 7.9%
Factor Correlations: ML2 = .25, ML3 = -.22, ML5 = -.31,

ML4 = -.19, ML6 = -.06

Variables:

  1. E2, Find it difficult to approach others. (Positive, Strong, .686)
  2. E1, Don’t talk a lot. (Positive, Strong, .587)
  3. E4, Make friends easily. (Negative, Strong, -.550)
  4. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .436)
  5. E5, Take charge. (Negative, Moderate, -.405)
  6. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Weak, .355)
  7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Negative, Weak, -.349)

LLM Interpretation:
ML1 captures Introversion, characterized by low social engagement and limited verbal expression. The factor is anchored by high loadings on ‘don’t talk a lot’ (E1) and ‘find it difficult to approach others’ (E2), while inversely loading on ‘captivate people’ (E3), ‘make friends easily’ (E4), and ‘take charge’ (E5). Convergent validity is clear: all items reflect reduced outward sociability. Discriminant validity is evident through minimal overlap with Neuroticism (ML2) and Conscientiousness (ML3). Correlations reveal a modest positive association with Negative Affect (ML2) and weak negative links with Openness (ML4) and Agreeableness (ML5), confirming its distinctiveness.

Factor 3 (ML3):: Conscientiousness

Number of significant loadings: 5
Variance explained: 7.71%
Factor Correlations: ML2 = -.18, ML1 = -.22, ML5 = .19,

ML4 = .19, ML6 = -.03

Variables:

  1. C2, Continue until everything is perfect. (Positive, Strong, .680)
  2. C4, Do things in a half-way manner. (Negative, Strong, -.634)
  3. C3, Do things according to a plan. (Positive, Strong, .551)
  4. C1, Am exacting in my work. (Positive, Strong, .547)
  5. C5, Waste my time. (Negative, Strong, -.541)

LLM Interpretation:
ML3 represents Conscientiousness, reflecting orderliness and goal‑directed behavior. It is defined by strong positive loadings on ‘exacting in my work’ (C1), ‘continue until everything is perfect’ (C2), and ‘do things according to a plan’ (C3), and strong negative loadings on ‘do things in a half‑way manner’ (C4) and ‘waste my time’ (C5). Convergent validity is evident as all items capture self‑discipline and diligence. Discriminant validity is supported by low loadings on the other personality factors. Correlations show a weak negative link with Introversion (ML1) and a slight positive association with Openness (ML4), indicating a distinct construct.

Factor 4 (ML5):: Agreeableness

Number of significant loadings: 5
Variance explained: 6.79%
Factor Correlations: ML2 = -.10, ML1 = -.31, ML3 = .19,

ML4 = .25, ML6 = .14

Variables:

  1. A2, Inquire about others’ well-being. (Positive, Strong, .688)
  2. A3, Know how to comfort others. (Positive, Strong, .617)
  3. A1, Am indifferent to the feelings of others. (Negative, Strong, -.560)
  4. A5, Make people feel at ease. (Positive, Moderate, .451)
  5. A4, Love children. (Positive, Weak, .391)

LLM Interpretation:
ML5 captures Agreeableness, the tendency to be warm and cooperative. It is defined by high loadings on ‘inquire about others’ (A2), ‘know how to comfort others’ (A3), ‘love children’ (A4), and ‘make people feel at ease’ (A5), while loading negatively on ‘am indifferent to the feelings of others’ (A1). Convergent validity is clear: all items reflect empathy and prosocial orientation. Discriminant validity is evident through low loadings on the other factors. Correlations reveal a modest negative link with Introversion (ML1) and a small positive association with Openness (ML4), underscoring its distinctiveness.

Factor 5 (ML4):: Openness

Number of significant loadings: 6
Variance explained: 6.27%
Factor Correlations: ML2 = .02, ML1 = -.19, ML3 = .19,

ML5 = .25, ML6 = .02

Variables:

  1. O3, Carry the conversation to a higher level. (Positive, Strong, .656)
  2. O1, Am full of ideas. (Positive, Strong, .564)
  3. O5, Will not probe deeply into a subject. (Negative, Moderate, -.451)
  4. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Positive, Weak, .392)
  5. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Weak, .376)
  6. O2, Avoid difficult reading material. (Negative, Weak, -.367)

LLM Interpretation:
ML4 represents Openness to Experience, capturing intellectual curiosity and imaginative engagement. It is defined by strong positive loadings on ‘am full of ideas’ (O1), ‘carry the conversation to a higher level’ (O3), and ‘spend time reflecting on things’ (O4), and negative loadings on ‘avoid difficult reading material’ (O2) and ‘will not probe deeply into a subject’ (O5). Convergent validity is evident as all items reflect openness to new ideas. Discriminant validity is supported by low loadings on the other factors. Correlations show a modest positive link with Conscientiousness (ML3) and a small negative association with Introversion (ML1), confirming its distinctiveness.

Factor 6 (ML6):: Low Openness/Agreeableness

Number of significant loadings: 2
Variance explained: 3.12%
Factor Correlations: ML2 = .18, ML1 = -.06, ML3 = -.03,

ML5 = .14, ML4 = .02

Variables:

  1. O5, Will not probe deeply into a subject. (Positive, Moderate, .403)
  2. O2, Avoid difficult reading material. (Positive, Weak, .353)

LLM Interpretation:
ML6 captures a blend of low Openness and low Agreeableness, shown by strong loadings on ‘avoid difficult reading material’ (O2), ‘will not probe deeply into a subject’ (O5), and ‘am indifferent to the feelings of others’ (A1). It also loads moderately on ‘love children’ (A4), ‘make people feel at ease’ (A5), and ‘make friends easily’ (E4), indicating a socially outgoing but superficial. Convergent validity is clear from superficiality and indifference. Discriminant validity is supported by from Openness and Agreeableness. Correlations show a weak positive link with Negative Affect (ML2) and a small negative association with Introversion (ML1), underscoring its unique profile.

Cross-Loading Variables

Variables loading on multiple factors (>= 0.3):

  • E3: Know how to captivate people.: ML1 (-.349), ML4 (.392)
  • N4: Often feel blue.: ML2 (.389), ML1 (.436)
  • O2: Avoid difficult reading material.: ML4 (-.367), ML6 (.353)
  • O4: Spend time reflecting on things.: ML1 (.355), ML4 (.376)
  • O5: Will not probe deeply into a subject.: ML4 (-.451), ML6 (.403)

Let’s check the global token usage tracked by the chat:

Code
print(chat)

Plot the loading matrix with factor names:

Code
plot(result,
     cutoff = 0.3)

Export Functionality

We can export the results to multiple formats

Code
# TXT export
export_interpretation(result,
                      format = "txt",
                      file = here("exports", "bfi_analysis"))
# MD export
export_interpretation(result,
                      format = "md",
                      file = here("exports", "bfi_analysis"))

Generic Methods for ‘psych’, ‘lavaan’, and ‘mirt’ Objects

psych Package

Code
interpret(
  fa_result,
  variable_info = variable_info,
  cutoff = 0.3,
  chat_session = chat,
  word_limit = 100,
  heading_level = 3,
  suppress_heading = TRUE,
  output_format = "markdown"
)

Variables:

  4. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .436)

  7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Negative, Weak, -.349)

LLM Interpretation:

The factor is anchored by high loadings on ‘don’t talk a lot’ (E1) and ‘find it difficult to approach others’ (E2), while inversely loading on ‘captivate people’ (E3), ‘make friends easily’ (E4), and ‘take charge’ (E5). Convergent validity is clear: all items reflect reduced outward sociability. Discriminant validity is evident through minimal overlap with Neuroticism (ML2) and Conscientiousness (ML3). Correlations reveal a modest positive association with Negative Affect (ML2) and weak negative links with Openness (ML4) and Agreeableness (ML5), confirming its distinctiveness.

lavaan Package

Code
# Specify a CFA model for BFI data
fa_lavaan <- lavaan::efa(bfi, nfactors = pa_result$nfact, rotation = "oblimin")
# interpret lavaan model
interpret(
  fa_lavaan,
  variable_info = variable_info,
  cutoff = 0.3,
  chat_session = chat,
  word_limit = 100,
  heading_level = 3,
  suppress_heading = TRUE,
  output_format = "markdown"
)

Also works with lavaa::cfa():

Code
# specify and fit a CFA model
cfa_model <- "
  O =~ O1 + O2 + O3 + O4 + O5
  C =~ C1 + C2 + C3 + C4 + C5
  E =~ E1 + E2 + E3 + E4 + E5
  A =~ A1 + A2 + A3 + A4 + A5
  N =~ N1 + N2 + N3 + N4 + N5
  "
cfa_fit <- lavaan::cfa(cfa_model, data = bfi, std.lv = TRUE)

# interpret lavaan cfa model
interpret(
  cfa_fit,
  variable_info = variable_info,
  cutoff = 0.3,
  chat_session = chat,
  word_limit = 100,
  output_format = "markdown",
  heading_level = 3,
  suppress_heading = TRUE
)

# interpret mirt model
interpret(
  irt_model,
  variable_info = variable_info,
  cutoff = 0.3,
  chat_session = chat,
  word_limit = 100,
  heading_level = 3,
  suppress_heading = TRUE,
  output_format = "markdown"
)
